groups.name: Animals that rhyme with color names
Things you wear on your feet
Things found in a kitchen sink

easy.notes: Easy groupings with concrete, familiar items. Group 1 uses rhyme-like relation: cat/bat/rat/mat rhyme with color names (red, blue, etc.) though not perfect, they share -at endings. Near-miss: 'mat' could be considered furniture, but here it's chosen for rhyme. Group 2 are common footwear. Group 3 easy flyables. Group 4 common kitchen sink items.

groups.name: Words that form new words with 'sun' prefix
Parts of a day: morning, afternoon, evening, night
Common playground items: see-saw, slide, swing, hoop

medium.notes: Medium groups introduce light wordplay: Group 1 uses words that pair with 'sun' to form new terms. Group 2 centers on times of day with related synonyms. Group 3 lists playground equipment. Group 4 uses common compound words ending in 'light'. Near-miss: 'sunbath' could be a stretch, but is a valid compound with sun- prefix; it’s kept to fit the list.

groups.name: Animal clues that hint at sounds they make
Items that share a common tool used for crafts
Words that pair with 'stick' to form common phrases

hard.notes: Hard rules include more abstract connections. Group 1 uses color idioms describing emotions; near-miss would be thinking literal color names, but phrases are needed. Group 2 pairs animal sounds with their vocalizations; very direct, but ensure students map sound to animal. Group 3 centers on craft supplies typically used together. Group 4 uses phrase constructions with 'stick' where some options (like 'password stick') are not valid phrases; stick figure and drum stick are valid; others are near-misses to demonstrate why they don’t fit. Ensure kids focus on common, unambiguous phrases.
